segment.source: OEM deployment of Windows 10 for desktop editions
segment.target: OEM deployment of Windows 10 for desktop editions

segment.source: This guide documents a prescriptive method for Windows 10 deployment using the classic deployment tools.
segment.target: This guide documents a prescriptive method for Windows 10 deployment using the classic deployment tools.

segment.source: Many of the tools and methods used in a Windows 8.1 classic deployment are applicable to Windows 10.
segment.target: Many of the tools and methods used in a Windows 8.1 classic deployment are applicable to Windows 10.

segment.source: The biggest change is the recovery process, where Windows 10 enables image-less recovery.
segment.target: The biggest change is the recovery process, where Windows 10 enables image-less recovery.

segment.source: This guide is intended for OEMs, and applies to Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education).
segment.target: This guide is intended for OEMs, and applies to Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education).

segment.source: IT professionals using this guide should have prior knowledge of Windows basic administration and troubleshooting.
segment.target: IT professionals using this guide should have prior knowledge of Windows basic administration and troubleshooting.

segment.source: For more information about what's new in Windows 10 deployment, see Windows 10 Deployment and Tools.
segment.target: For more information about what's new in Windows 10 deployment, see Windows 10 Deployment and Tools.

segment.source: Deployment and imaging tools environment
segment.target: Deployment and imaging tools environment

segment.source: The Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) is a collection of tools and documentation that OEMs, ODMs, and IT Professionals use to customize, assess, and deploy Windows operating systems to new computers.
segment.target: The Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) is a collection of tools and documentation that OEMs, ODMs, and IT Professionals use to customize, assess, and deploy Windows operating systems to new computers.

segment.source: Deployment tools enable you to customize, manage, and deploy Windows images.
segment.target: Deployment tools enable you to customize, manage, and deploy Windows images.

segment.source: They can also be used to automate Windows deployments, removing the need for user interaction during Windows setup.
segment.target: They can also be used to automate Windows deployments, removing the need for user interaction during Windows setup.

segment.source: You must use the matching version of the Windows ADK for the images that you plan to customize.
segment.target: You must use the matching version of the Windows ADK for the images that you plan to customize.

segment.source: For example, if you are customizing an image based on Windows 10, version 1511, you must use the Windows ADK from Windows 10, version 1511.
segment.target: For example, if you are customizing an image based on Windows 10, version 1511, you must use the Windows ADK from Windows 10, version 1511.

segment.target: To complete the steps outlined in this guide, OEMs will require:

segment.source: A Technician computer: A PC running Windows 10 or Windows 8.1 on which Windows ADK will be installed.
segment.target: A Technician computer: A PC running Windows 10 or Windows 8.1 on which Windows ADK will be installed.

segment.source: 32-bit PCs require a 32-bit version of Windows to use some tools.
segment.target: 32-bit PCs require a 32-bit version of Windows to use some tools.

segment.target: Note: This guide provides sample Windows PowerShell script to automate offline servicing section.

segment.source: In order to use this script, you will need a Technician computer running Windows 10.
segment.target: In order to use this script, you will need a Technician computer running Windows 10.

segment.source: A Reference computer: A PC that represents all of the PCs in a single model line; for example, the Fabrikam Notebook PC Series.
segment.target: A Reference computer: A PC that represents all of the PCs in a single model line; for example, the Fabrikam Notebook PC Series.

segment.source: For this PC, choose from something that resembles the Hardware Configuration Table.
segment.target: For this PC, choose from something that resembles the Hardware Configuration Table.

segment.source: Create an answer file
segment.target: Create an answer file

segment.source: An "answer file" is an XML-based file that contains setting definitions and values to use during Windows Setup.
segment.target: An "answer file" is an XML-based file that contains setting definitions and values to use during Windows Setup.

segment.source: In an answer file, you specify various setup options, including how to partition disks, the location of the Windows image to install, and the product key to apply.
segment.target: In an answer file, you specify various setup options, including how to partition disks, the location of the Windows image to install, and the product key to apply.

segment.source: Values that apply to the Windows installation, such as the names of user accounts, display settings, and Internet Explorer Favorites can also be specified.
segment.target: Values that apply to the Windows installation, such as the names of user accounts, display settings, and Internet Explorer Favorites can also be specified.

segment.source: The answer file for Setup is typically called Unattend.xml.
segment.target: The answer file for Setup is typically called Unattend.xml.

segment.source: Answer files created in Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM) are associated with a particular Windows image.
segment.target: Answer files created in Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM) are associated with a particular Windows image.

segment.source: This enables validating the settings in the answer file to the settings available in the Windows image.
segment.target: This enables validating the settings in the answer file to the settings available in the Windows image.

segment.source: However, because any answer file can be used to install any Windows image, if there are settings in the answer file for components that do not exist in the Windows image, those settings are ignored.
segment.target: However, because any answer file can be used to install any Windows image, if there are settings in the answer file for components that do not exist in the Windows image, those settings are ignored.

segment.source: The Start tile layout in Windows 10 provides OEMs the ability to append tiles to the default Start layout to include Web links, secondary tiles, classic Windows applications, and universal Windows apps.
segment.target: The Start tile layout in Windows 10 provides OEMs the ability to append tiles to the default Start layout to include Web links, secondary tiles, classic Windows applications, and universal Windows apps.

segment.source: OEMs can use this layout to make it applicable to multiple regions or markets without duplicating a lot of the work.
segment.target: OEMs can use this layout to make it applicable to multiple regions or markets without duplicating a lot of the work.

segment.source: In addition, OEMs can add up to three default apps to the frequently used apps section in the system area, which delivers sytem-driven lists to the user, including important or frequently accessed system locations and recently installed apps.
segment.target: In addition, OEMs can add up to three default apps to the frequently used apps section in the system area, which delivers sytem-driven lists to the user, including important or frequently accessed system locations and recently installed apps.

segment.source: To take advantage of all these new features and have the most robust and complete Start customization experience for Windows 10, consider creating a LayoutModification.xml file.
segment.target: To take advantage of all these new features and have the most robust and complete Start customization experience for Windows 10, consider creating a LayoutModification.xml file.

segment.source: This file specifies how the OEM tiles should be laid out in Start.
segment.target: This file specifies how the OEM tiles should be laid out in Start.

segment.source: For more information about how to customize the new Start layout, see Customize the Windows 10 Start screen.
segment.target: For more information about how to customize the new Start layout, see Customize the Windows 10 Start screen.

segment.source: Create Layoutmodification.xml.
segment.target: Create Layoutmodification.xml.

segment.source: Note: It is recommended to start with the sample on USB-B\StartLayout\layoutModification.xml as it conforms to the samples in this document (example only).
segment.target: Note: It is recommended to start with the sample on USB-B\StartLayout\layoutModification.xml as it conforms to the samples in this document (example only).

segment.source: The Sample LayoutModification.xml shows two groups called “Fabrikam Group 1" and “Fabrikam Group 2”, which contain tiles that will be applied if the device country/region matches what’s specified in Region (in this case, the regions are Germany and United States).
segment.target: The Sample LayoutModification.xml shows two groups called “Fabrikam Group 1" and “Fabrikam Group 2”, which contain tiles that will be applied if the device country/region matches what’s specified in Region (in this case, the regions are Germany and United States).

segment.source: Each group contains three tiles and the various elements you need to use depending on the tile that you want to pin to Start.
segment.target: Each group contains three tiles and the various elements you need to use depending on the tile that you want to pin to Start.

segment.source: Keep the following in mind when creating your LayoutModification.xml file:
segment.target: Keep the following in mind when creating your LayoutModification.xml file:

segment.source: If you are pinning a Classic Windows application using the start:DesktopApplicationTile tag and you don’t know the application’s application user model ID, you need to create a .lnk file in a legacy Start Menu directory before first boot.
segment.target: If you are pinning a Classic Windows application using the start:DesktopApplicationTile tag and you don’t know the application’s application user model ID, you need to create a .lnk file in a legacy Start Menu directory before first boot.

segment.source: If you use the start:DesktopApplicationTile tag to pin a legacy .url shortcut to Start, you must create a .url file and add this file to a legacy Start Menu directory before first boot.
segment.target: If you use the start:DesktopApplicationTile tag to pin a legacy .url shortcut to Start, you must create a .url file and add this file to a legacy Start Menu directory before first boot.

segment.source: For those scenarios, you can use the following directories to put the .url or .lnk files:
segment.target: For those scenarios, you can use the following directories to put the .url or .lnk files:

segment.source: %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\
segment.target: %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\

segment.source: %ALLUSERSPROFILE%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\
segment.target: %ALLUSERSPROFILE%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\

segment.source: Save the LayoutModification.xml file.
segment.target: Save the LayoutModification.xml file.

segment.source: Add your LayoutModification.xml file to the Windows image.
segment.target: Add your LayoutModification.xml file to the Windows image.

segment.source: You’ll need to put the file in the following specific location before first boot.
segment.target: You’ll need to put the file in the following specific location before first boot.

segment.source: If the file exists, you should replace the LayoutModification.XML that is already included in the image.
segment.target: If the file exists, you should replace the LayoutModification.XML that is already included in the image.

segment.target: If you pinned tiles that require .url or .lnk files, add the files to the following legacy Start Menu directories :

segment.source: Note: If you don’t create a LayoutModification.xml file and you continue to use the Start Unattend settings, the OS will use the Unattend answer file and take the first 12 SquareTiles or DesktoporSquareTiles settings specified in the Unattend file.
segment.target: Note: If you don’t create a LayoutModification.xml file and you continue to use the Start Unattend settings, the OS will use the Unattend answer file and take the first 12 SquareTiles or DesktoporSquareTiles settings specified in the Unattend file.

segment.source: The system then places these tiles automatically within the newly-created groups at the end of Start—the first six tiles are placed in the first OEM group and the second set of six tiles are placed in the second OEM group.
segment.target: The system then places these tiles automatically within the newly-created groups at the end of Start—the first six tiles are placed in the first OEM group and the second set of six tiles are placed in the second OEM group.

segment.target: If OEMName is specified in the Unattend file, the value for this element is used to name the OEM groups that will be created.

segment.source: Add an OEM-specific license
segment.target: Add an OEM-specific license

segment.source: An OEM may add its OEM license terms to the License Terms screen in the first experience.
segment.target: An OEM may add its OEM license terms to the License Terms screen in the first experience.

segment.source: Note: If the license terms are included, the OEM must include a version of the license terms in each language that is preinstalled onto the PC.
segment.target: Note: If the license terms are included, the OEM must include a version of the license terms in each language that is preinstalled onto the PC.

segment.source: A license term text must be an .rtf file, saved as .rtf format.
segment.target: A license term text must be an .rtf file, saved as .rtf format.

segment.target: Name each folder under C:\mount\windows\Windows\System32\oobe\info\default\ directory as the Language Decimal Identifier corresponding the language.

segment.source: Do this step for each language pack added to the Windows image.
segment.target: Do this step for each language pack added to the Windows image.

segment.source: For the complete list of language decimal identifiers of corresponding languages, see Available Language Packs for Windows.
segment.target: For the complete list of language decimal identifiers of corresponding languages, see Available Language Packs for Windows.

segment.source: For example, if en-us and de-de language packs are added to the Windows image, add a folder named “1033” (representing en-us language) under C:\mount\windows\Windows\System32\oobe\info\default Then add a folder named “1031” (representing de-de language) under the same directory.
segment.target: For example, if en-us and de-de language packs are added to the Windows image, add a folder named “1033” (representing en-us language) under C:\mount\windows\Windows\System32\oobe\info\default Then add a folder named “1031” (representing de-de language) under the same directory.

segment.source: Use the following partition layout size guidance to determine the size of your recovery partition in createartitions-firmware.txt files.
segment.target: Use the following partition layout size guidance to determine the size of your recovery partition in createartitions-firmware.txt files.

segment.source: The amount of free space left is after you copy winre.wim to the hidden partition.
segment.target: The amount of free space left is after you copy winre.wim to the hidden partition.

segment.source: Please reference Disk Partition rules for more information.
segment.target: Please reference Disk Partition rules for more information.

segment.source: If the partition is less than 500 MB, it must have at least 50 MB of free space.
segment.target: If the partition is less than 500 MB, it must have at least 50 MB of free space.

segment.source: If the partition is 500 MB or larger, it must have at least 320 MB of free space.
segment.target: If the partition is 500 MB or larger, it must have at least 320 MB of free space.

segment.source: If the partition is larger than 1 GB, we recommend that it should have at least 1 GB free.
segment.target: If the partition is larger than 1 GB, we recommend that it should have at least 1 GB free.

segment.target: Boot to WinPE

segment.target: After WinPE has been booted, connect USB-B.

segment.source: At the X:\Windows\system32 command line,type diskpart and press Enter to start Diskpart.
segment.target: At the X:\Windows\system32 command line,type diskpart and press Enter to start Diskpart.

segment.source: At the \DISKPART command line, type list volume.
segment.target: At the \DISKPART command line, type list volume.

segment.source: Under the “Label” column, identify the USB-B drive and note the letter of the volume under the “Ltr” column (for example, E).
segment.target: Under the “Label” column, identify the USB-B drive and note the letter of the volume under the “Ltr” column (for example, E).

segment.target: Type exit to quit Diskpart.

segment.source: Deploy the image
segment.target: Deploy the image

segment.source: Using the deployment script walkthrough-deploy.bat in USB-B/Deployment folder, lay out the partitions on the device and apply the image.
segment.target: Using the deployment script walkthrough-deploy.bat in USB-B/Deployment folder, lay out the partitions on the device and apply the image.

segment.source: Important: The Recovery partition must be the partition after the Windows partition to ensure winre.wim can be kept up-to-date during life of the device.
segment.target: Important: The Recovery partition must be the partition after the Windows partition to ensure winre.wim can be kept up-to-date during life of the device.

segment.source: In Windows 10 Version 1511, we are changing our recommendation to have the WinRE partition placed after the OS partition.
segment.target: In Windows 10 Version 1511, we are changing our recommendation to have the WinRE partition placed after the OS partition.

segment.source: This allows future growth of the WinRE partition during updates.
segment.target: This allows future growth of the WinRE partition during updates.

segment.source: Today with the WinRE partition at the front of the disk, the size of it can never be changed, making it difficult to update WinRE when needed.
segment.target: Today with the WinRE partition at the front of the disk, the size of it can never be changed, making it difficult to update WinRE when needed.

segment.source: We will continue to support having the WinRE partition located in different parts of the disk, but we encourage you to follow the new recommendation.
segment.target: We will continue to support having the WinRE partition located in different parts of the disk, but we encourage you to follow the new recommendation.

segment.target: There are several pauses in the script.

segment.target: You will be prompted Y/N for the Apply operation if this is a Compact OS deployment.

segment.target: Note: Only use Compact OS on Flash drive based devices because Compact OS performance depends heavily on the storage device capabilities.

segment.source: Compact OS is NOT recommended on rotational devices.

segment.source: Setup mode
segment.target: Setup mode

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: OEM
segment.target: OEM

segment.source: In this mode, a customer can choose to try, buy, or activate Office with an existing account, PIN, or product key.
segment.target: In this mode, a customer can choose to try, buy, or activate Office with an existing account, PIN, or product key.

segment.source: This mode doesn’t support Activation for Office (AFO) or AFO late binding.
segment.target: This mode doesn’t support Activation for Office (AFO) or AFO late binding.

segment.source: Therefore, if you choose this mode, you need to provide the customer with an Activation Card (formerly called a product key card or a Microsoft Product Identifier (MPI) card).
segment.target: Therefore, if you choose this mode, you need to provide the customer with an Activation Card (formerly called a product key card or a Microsoft Product Identifier (MPI) card).

segment.source: OEMTA
segment.target: OEMTA

segment.source: This mode supports the try, buy, or activate experience of the OEM mode as well as supporting AFO and AFO late binding.
segment.target: This mode supports the try, buy, or activate experience of the OEM mode as well as supporting AFO and AFO late binding.

segment.source: This mode supports Office activation through the device’s Windows product key, which means the customer wouldn’t need to enter a 5x5 product key code.
segment.target: This mode supports Office activation through the device’s Windows product key, which means the customer wouldn’t need to enter a 5x5 product key code.

segment.source: OEM Mode – Provide user with activation card
segment.target: OEM Mode – Provide user with activation card

segment.target: oemsetup.cmd Mode=OEM

segment.source: OEMTA Mode – Activation is done through the device’s Windows product key.
segment.target: OEMTA Mode – Activation is done through the device’s Windows product key.

segment.target: Preload Microsoft Office Single Image v15.4

segment.source: The current preload method of Office 2013 is different from other desktop apps.
segment.target: The current preload method of Office 2013 is different from other desktop apps.

segment.source: OEMs preinstall desktop apps so the apps are installed.
segment.target: OEMs preinstall desktop apps so the apps are installed.

segment.source: This means that when the user launches the app, the app is already installed and automatically opens with no additional installation tasks other than EULA acceptance and/or user registration.
segment.target: This means that when the user launches the app, the app is already installed and automatically opens with no additional installation tasks other than EULA acceptance and/or user registration.

segment.source: With Office, compressed setup files are copied to the disk in addition to an out-of-box experience (OOBE) application which captures Office file associations and gives users an entry point to Try, Buy or Activate Office.
segment.target: With Office, compressed setup files are copied to the disk in addition to an out-of-box experience (OOBE) application which captures Office file associations and gives users an entry point to Try, Buy or Activate Office.

segment.source: Users do not have access to Word or Excel on the Start screen or in the All Apps view until they launch Office OOBE which is typically made available as a tile on the Start screen.
segment.target: Users do not have access to Word or Excel on the Start screen or in the All Apps view until they launch Office OOBE which is typically made available as a tile on the Start screen.

segment.source: When the user launches Office OOBE, setup of Office begins.
segment.target: When the user launches Office OOBE, setup of Office begins.

segment.source: Once Office setup is complete, the compressed setup files that are no longer necessary are removed from the disk.
segment.target: Once Office setup is complete, the compressed setup files that are no longer necessary are removed from the disk.

segment.source: Pre-install Office single image (either with or without perpetual or subscription license) or Office Mobile.
segment.target: Pre-install Office single image (either with or without perpetual or subscription license) or Office Mobile.

segment.source: Office Mobile must be used on devices with screen size of 10.1" and below, and Office single image must be used on devices with screen sizes above 10.1".
segment.target: Office Mobile must be used on devices with screen size of 10.1" and below, and Office single image must be used on devices with screen sizes above 10.1".

segment.source: For devices that have a single fixed storage drive with less than 32 GB, OEMs may preinstall Office Mobile, regardless of the screen size.
segment.target: For devices that have a single fixed storage drive with less than 32 GB, OEMs may preinstall Office Mobile, regardless of the screen size.

segment.source: OEMs must have only one Office image on the customer system at a time.
segment.target: OEMs must have only one Office image on the customer system at a time.

segment.source: Pin Office tiles to the Start Menu in such slots that are visible without scrolling, regardless of OEM Systems’ Start Menu layout, unless the Office Tiles or Office tile, as applicable, are pinned as part of the Microsoft Group of Start Menu tiles.
segment.target: Pin Office tiles to the Start Menu in such slots that are visible without scrolling, regardless of OEM Systems’ Start Menu layout, unless the Office Tiles or Office tile, as applicable, are pinned as part of the Microsoft Group of Start Menu tiles.

segment.source: Prepare system for recovery push-button reset scenarios
segment.target: Prepare system for recovery push-button reset scenarios

segment.source: Push-button reset, first introduced in Windows 8, is a built-in recovery tool that allows users to recover the OS while preserving their data and important customizations, without having to back-up their data in advance.
segment.target: Push-button reset, first introduced in Windows 8, is a built-in recovery tool that allows users to recover the OS while preserving their data and important customizations, without having to back-up their data in advance.

segment.source: It reduces the need for custom recovery applications by providing users with more recovery options and the ability to fix their own PCs with confidence.
segment.target: It reduces the need for custom recovery applications by providing users with more recovery options and the ability to fix their own PCs with confidence.

segment.source: In Windows 10, the Push-button reset features have been updated to include the following improvements:
segment.target: In Windows 10, the Push-button reset features have been updated to include the following improvements:

segment.source: Image-less recovery
segment.target: Image-less recovery

segment.source: Push-button reset features no longer require or support a separate recovery image on a local partition or on media.
segment.target: Push-button reset features no longer require or support a separate recovery image on a local partition or on media.

segment.source: This significantly reduces the disk space needed to support the features, and makes recovery possible even on devices with limited storage capacity.
segment.target: This significantly reduces the disk space needed to support the features, and makes recovery possible even on devices with limited storage capacity.

segment.source: Recovers to an updated state
segment.target: Recovers to an updated state

segment.source: Push-button reset features now recover the Operating System (OS) and drivers (including device applets that are installed as part of INF-based driver packages) to an updated state.
segment.target: Push-button reset features now recover the Operating System (OS) and drivers (including device applets that are installed as part of INF-based driver packages) to an updated state.

segment.source: This reduces the amount of time users have to spend reinstalling the OS updates and drivers after performing a recovery.
segment.target: This reduces the amount of time users have to spend reinstalling the OS updates and drivers after performing a recovery.

segment.source: The Push-button reset user experience continues to offer customization opportunities.
segment.target: The Push-button reset user experience continues to offer customization opportunities.

segment.source: Manufacturers can insert custom scripts, install applications or preserve additional data at available extensibility points.
segment.target: Manufacturers can insert custom scripts, install applications or preserve additional data at available extensibility points.

segment.source: The following Push-button reset features are available to users with Windows 10 PCs:
segment.target: The following Push-button reset features are available to users with Windows 10 PCs:

segment.source: Refresh your PC
segment.target: Refresh your PC

segment.source: Fixes software problems by reinstalling the OS while preserving the user data, user accounts, and important settings.
segment.target: Fixes software problems by reinstalling the OS while preserving the user data, user accounts, and important settings.

segment.source: All other preinstalled customizations are restored to their factory state.
segment.target: All other preinstalled customizations are restored to their factory state.

segment.source: In Windows 10, this feature no longer preserves user-acquired Universal Windows apps1.
segment.target: In Windows 10, this feature no longer preserves user-acquired Universal Windows apps1.

segment.source: Reset your PC
segment.target: Reset your PC

segment.source: Prepares the PC for recycling or for transfer of ownership by reinstalling the OS, removing all user accounts and contents (e.g. data, Classic Windows applications, and Universal Windows apps), and restoring preinstalled customizations to their factory state.
segment.target: Prepares the PC for recycling or for transfer of ownership by reinstalling the OS, removing all user accounts and contents (e.g. data, Classic Windows applications, and Universal Windows apps), and restoring preinstalled customizations to their factory state.

segment.source: Bare metal recovery
segment.target: Bare metal recovery

segment.source: Restores the default or preconfigured partition layout on the system disk, and reinstalls the OS and preinstalled customizations from external media.
segment.target: Restores the default or preconfigured partition layout on the system disk, and reinstalls the OS and preinstalled customizations from external media.

segment.source: For more information, see:
segment.target: For more information, see:

segment.source: Push-button reset
segment.target: Push-button reset

segment.source: While turning on, if the system continues to boot from Internal HDD, Windows will enter the specialize pass and then the OOBE pass.

segment.target: The system restarts and boots in Audit mode.

segment.source: In Audit mode, Sysprep the system by using the OOBE Shutdown and Generalize switches, as explained previously.
segment.target: In Audit mode, Sysprep the system by using the OOBE Shutdown and Generalize switches, as explained previously.

segment.source: After the system reboots, make sure to boot from USB-A to WinPE.
segment.target: After the system reboots, make sure to boot from USB-A to WinPE.

segment.source: If the system still boots with internal HDD, please make sure USB boot is prioritized instead of HDD boot.
segment.target: If the system still boots with internal HDD, please make sure USB boot is prioritized instead of HDD boot.

segment.source: To do so, it may be necessary to enter the Reference Computer BIOS menu and adjust the boot priority order so that the USB Key is at the top of the list.
segment.target: To do so, it may be necessary to enter the Reference Computer BIOS menu and adjust the boot priority order so that the USB Key is at the top of the list.

segment.source: Identify Windows Partition Drive letter.
segment.target: Identify Windows Partition Drive letter.

segment.source: At the X:\windows\system32 prompt, type diskpart and press the Enter key to start Diskpart.
segment.target: At the X:\windows\system32 prompt, type diskpart and press the Enter key to start Diskpart.

segment.source: At the \DISKPART prompt type list volume.
segment.target: At the \DISKPART prompt type list volume.

segment.source: Under the “Label” column, locate the volume that is labeled “Windows”.
segment.target: Under the “Label” column, locate the volume that is labeled “Windows”.

segment.source: Note what letter it is has been assigned under the “Ltr” column (Example: C).
segment.target: Note what letter it is has been assigned under the “Ltr” column (Example: C).

segment.source: This is the drive letter that needs to be used.
segment.target: This is the drive letter that needs to be used.

segment.source: Type exit to quit Diskpart.
segment.target: Type exit to quit Diskpart.

segment.source: Diskpart
segment.target: Diskpart

segment.target: Switch to the Technician Computer and mount the image.

segment.source: Important: By default, non-major updates (e.g. ZDPs, KB’s, LCUs) are not restored.
segment.target: Important: By default, non-major updates (e.g. ZDPs, KB’s, LCUs) are not restored.

segment.source: To ensure that updates preinstalled during manufacturing are not discarded after recovery, they should be marked as permanent by using the /Cleanup-Image command in DISM with the /StartComponentCleanup and [/ResetBase [/Defer]] options.
segment.target: To ensure that updates preinstalled during manufacturing are not discarded after recovery, they should be marked as permanent by using the /Cleanup-Image command in DISM with the /StartComponentCleanup and [/ResetBase [/Defer]] options.

segment.source: Updates marked as permanent are always restored during recovery.
segment.target: Updates marked as permanent are always restored during recovery.

segment.source: Running this is a must to retain updates applied during manufacturing in order for PBR to restore them in first 28 days.
segment.target: Running this is a must to retain updates applied during manufacturing in order for PBR to restore them in first 28 days.

segment.source: Promoted Apps are installed right after OOBE on Windows 10 PCs.

segment.source: Verify recovery
segment.target: Verify recovery

segment.source: Verify that your customizations are restored after recovery, and that they continue to function by running the Refresh your PC and Reset your PC features from the following entry points:
segment.target: Verify that your customizations are restored after recovery, and that they continue to function by running the Refresh your PC and Reset your PC features from the following entry points:

segment.source: Settings
segment.target: Settings

segment.source: From the Start Menu, click Settings.
segment.target: From the Start Menu, click Settings.

segment.source: In the Settings app, click Update & security, and then click Recovery.
segment.target: In the Settings app, click Update & security, and then click Recovery.

segment.source: Click Get Started under Reset this PC and follow the on-screen instructions.
segment.target: Click Get Started under Reset this PC and follow the on-screen instructions.

segment.source: Windows RE
segment.target: Windows RE

segment.source: From the Choose an option screen in Windows RE, click Troubleshoot.
segment.target: From the Choose an option screen in Windows RE, click Troubleshoot.

segment.source: Click Reset this PC and then follow the on-screen instructions.
segment.target: Click Reset this PC and then follow the on-screen instructions.

segment.source: Verify that recovery media can be created, and verify its functionality by running the bare metal recovery feature:
segment.target: Verify that recovery media can be created, and verify its functionality by running the bare metal recovery feature:

segment.source: Launch Create a recovery drive from Control Panel.
segment.target: Launch Create a recovery drive from Control Panel.

segment.source: Follow the on-screen instructions to create the USB recovery drive.
segment.target: Follow the on-screen instructions to create the USB recovery drive.

segment.source: Boot the PC from the USB recovery drive.
segment.target: Boot the PC from the USB recovery drive.

segment.source: From the Choose an option screen, click Troubleshoot.
segment.target: From the Choose an option screen, click Troubleshoot.

segment.source: Click Recover from a drive and then follow the on-screen instructions.
segment.target: Click Recover from a drive and then follow the on-screen instructions.

segment.source: Note: The Push-button reset UI has been redesigned in Windows 10.
segment.target: Note: The Push-button reset UI has been redesigned in Windows 10.

segment.source: The Keep my files option in the UI now corresponds to the Refresh your PC feature, whereas the Remove everything option corresponds to the Reset your PC feature.
segment.target: The Keep my files option in the UI now corresponds to the Refresh your PC feature, whereas the Remove everything option corresponds to the Reset your PC feature.
